conclusion: Complex problem involving a slider sliding down an inclined track, colliding with a ball, which then goes through various curved paths and finally lands on the ground after colliding with a triangular prism.
Need to break down the problem step by step.
Understanding the setup: horizontal platform of height H = 0.4 m.

Several tracks on the platform: rough inclined track AB with angle θ = 37°, horizontal smooth track BC, quarter-circular smooth pipe CD with radius r = 0.1 m, semi-circular smooth track DEF with radius R = 0.2 m.
Points O1, D, O2, and F are on the same horizontal line.
Small slider starts from rest at point P on track AB, at height h above the platform.
Slider slides down and undergoes elastic collision with a small ball of equal mass at rest on track BC.
After collision, ball passes through pipe CD and track DEF, moves vertically downwards from point F, collides with triangular prism G, and lands at point Q on the ground.
Coefficient of kinetic friction between slider and track AB is μ = 1/12.
Minimum value of h for ball to complete motion is 0.45 m.
Ball just barely passes highest point E.
Position of triangular prism G is adjustable vertically.
Need to find maximum horizontal distance x_max between landing point Q and point F.
Analyzing motion of slider from point P down inclined track AB.
Slider starts from rest at point P, height h above platform.
Track AB is inclined at θ = 37°.
Friction with coefficient μ = 1/12.
Find velocity of slider at bottom of incline, just before collision with ball.
Distance from P to bottom of incline is L = 5h/3.
Work done by friction W_f = -mgh/9.
Change in gravitational potential energy is mgh.
Using work-energy theorem: ΔK = W_net = mgh - mgh/9 = 8mgh/9.
